page.title: Timeline of women's rights (other than voting)

revision.text:
{{Feminism sidebar}} [[File:Trotula of Salerno.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Trotula of Salerno]]]] [[File:Laura Bassi - Carlo Vandi.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Laura Bassi]]. The first female professor in Europe]] [[File:Emilie du Châtelet.jpg|xp200|right|thumb|[[Émilie du Châtelet]].]] [[File:Stamps of Germany (Berlin) 1988, MiNr 824.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Dorothea Erxleben]]. The first female doctor in Germany]] [[File:EBlackwell1905.jpg|thumb|200px|Portrait of [[Elizabeth Blackwell]] by [[Joseph S. Kozlowski|Joseph Stanley Kozlowski]], 1905. Syracuse University Medical School collection.]] [[File:Suffrage parade-New York City-May 6 1912.jpg|thumb|200px|Suffrage parade, New York City, May 6, 1912.]]
The timeline signifies the major events in the development of women's rights and issues of gender inequality. It does not concentrate merely on the right to vote ([[Timeline of women's suffrage]]).
== Before the 19th century == ; 1718 * Russia: Gender segregation is banned<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> * Sweden: Female taxpaying members of the cities' [[guild]]s are allowed to vote and stand for election during the [[age of liberty]]; this right is banned (for local elections) in 1758 and (general elections) in 1771<ref>Åsa Karlsson-Sjögren : Männen, kvinnorna och rösträtten: medborgarskap och representation 1723–1866 (Men, women and the vote: citizenship and representation 1723–1866){{sv icon}}</ref> * Province of Pennsylvania (now U.S. state of Pennsylvania): Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se">[http://books.google.se/books?id=cd0KqQ6rxfEC&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=connecticut+married+women+property+rights+1856&source=bl&ots=PuT48wsPNW&sig=wE8yf2eQSqTk5n5C1t8r6kIwcDQ&hl=sv&ei=oXLnToaWKLTc4QSE7c3vCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&sqi=2&ved=0CFcQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false B. Zorina Khan: The democratization of invention: patents and copyrights in American Economic Development 1790–1920]</ref> ; 1722 * Russia: Ban against forced marriages <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> ; 1753 * Russia: Married women granted separate economy <ref>Michelle Lamarche Marrese: A woman's kingdom: noblewomen and the control of property in Russia, 1700–1861</ref> ; 1754 * Germany: [[Dorothea Erxleben]] the first woman doctor. ; 1771 * New York: Husbands must have their wives' consent to sell their property<ref name="womenshistory.about.com">http://womenshistory.about.com/od/marriedwomensproperty/a/property_rights.htm</ref> ; 1774 * Maryland: Husbands must have their wives' consent to sell their property<ref name="womenshistory.about.com"/> ; 1776 * France: Female [[tailor]]s are allowed in to the [[guild]] of tailors<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=x_sjouorAeEC&pg=PA252&lpg=PA252&dq=guild+tailors+1776&source=bl&ots=dI_kALVI77&sig=4-NokUGQXnm04m00sQV5JBKeHsk&hl=sv&ei=U0jTTvLABuj44QS0seEj&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Fabricating women: the seamstresses of Old Regime France, 1675–1791 by Clare Haru Crowston]</ref> ; 1778 * Sweden: [[Barnamordsplakatet]]; unmarried women are allowed to leave their home town to give birth anonymously and have the birth registered anonymously, to refrain from answering any questions about the birth and, if they choose to keep their child, to have their unmarried status not mentioned in official documents to avoid social embarrassment. ; 1786 * Russia: Primary and high schools for females <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> ; 1787 * Massachusetts: The trade profession is opened to unmarried women<ref name="womenshistory.about.com"/> ; 1788 * France: noble widows are known to have voted to the [[French States-General]] in 1788–89 in the absence of a male guardian. * United States of America: Female citizens may stand for election for federal offices, though they still could not vote. ; 1789 * France is the first country in Europe where it is suggested that women are to be in the Assembly of the Estates, there are several demands to include women in the reforms of the right to vote. ; 1791 * France: Equal inheritance rights (abolished in 1804) <ref name="ReferenceB">[http://books.google.se/books?id=zYSiCSy9tx4C&pg=PA141&dq=france+women+inheritance+1790&hl=sv&ei=XznZTqXpK-j44QTv65TQDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false The Family on Trial in Revolutionary France by Suzanne Desan]</ref> ; 1792 * France: Divorce is legalized for both sexes<ref name="ReferenceB"/> (abolished for women in 1804) * France: Local women-units of the defense army are founded in several cities; although the military was never officially open to women, about eight thousand women were estimated to have served openly in the French armé in local troops (but not in the battle fields) between 1792 and 1794, but women were officially barred from the armé in 1795<ref name="ReferenceA">* Herman Lindqvist : Revolution (Revolution!) {{sv icon}}</ref> ; 1793 * France: The question of women's right to vote is discussed in the [[Parliament of France]]; women's right to vote is acknowledged as a principle, but it is still put aside with the explanation that the time is not right to make this a reality and is therefore postponed.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
== 19th century == ===1800–1860=== ; 1809 * USA, Connecticut: Married women are allowed to execute wills<ref name="womenshistory.about.com"/> ; 1810 * Sweden: The informal right of an unmarried woman to be declared of [[legal majority]] by royal dispensation are officially confirmed by parliament<ref>Christine Bladh (Swedish): ''Månglerskor: att sälja från korg och bod i Stockholm 1819–1846'' (1991)</ref> ; 1811 * Austria: Married women are granted separate economy and the right to choose profession<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979">Richard J Evans (1979). Kvinnorörelsens historia i Europa, USA, Australien och Nya Zeeland 1840–1920 (The Feminists: Women's Emancipation Movements in Europe, America and Australasia, 1840–1920) Helsingborg: LiberFörlag Stockholm. ISBN 91-38-04920-1 (Swedish)</ref> * Sweden: Married businesswomen are granted the right to make decisions about their own affairs without their husband's consent <ref name="ReferenceC">[http://books.google.se/books?id=rfIfkhOcZ7QC&pg=PA56&dq=kvinnor+n%C3%A4ringslivet+1864&hl=sv&ei=4t_TTob4CZPZ4QSduYTeBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false Mansdominans i förändring: om ledningsgrupper och styrelser : betänkande by Sverige Utredningen om kvinnor på ledande poster i näringslivet]</ref> ; 1821 * USA, Maine: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1827 * Brazil: The first elementary schools for girls and the profession of school teacher are open<ref>A companion to gender history by: Teresa A. Meade, Merry E. Wiesner-Hanks</ref> ; 1829 * India: [[Sati (practice)|Sati]] is banned. * Sweden: Midwifes are allowed to use surgical instruments, which are unique in Europe at the time and gives them surgical status<ref>{{sv icon}} Stig Hadenius, Torbjörn Nilsson & Gunnar Åselius: ''Sveriges historia. Vad varje svensk bör veta'' (''History of Sweden'': "What every Swede should know")</ref> ; 1833 * USA, [[Ohio]]: The first [[co-educational]] university, [[Oberlin College]]. * Guatemala: Divorce legalized (rescinded in 1840 and reintroduced in 1894) <ref>Women's Roles in Latin America and the Caribbean by Kathryn A. Sloan</ref> ; 1835 * USA, Arkansas: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Massachusetts: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Tennessee: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1839 * Great Britain: The [[Custody of Infants Act 1839]] makes it possible for divorced mothers to be granted custody of their children. * USA, [[Mississippi]]: The [[Married Women's Property Act 1839]] grants married women the right to own (but not control) property in her own name.<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=3mK6xQMF2wQC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=Mississippi+Married+women+1839&source=bl&ots=zWcfbt4ppO&sig=xY61RtDJTbMldNcFMhVE7xNeOos&hl=sv&ei=D1TTTsalBsre4QSslYAX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Mississippi%20Married%20women%201839&f=false Janet L. Coryell: Negotiating boundaries of southern womanhood]</ref> ; 1840 * USA, [[Texas]]: Married women allowed to own property in their own name<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=3mK6xQMF2wQC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=Mississippi+Married+women+1839&source=bl&ots=zWcfbt4ppO&sig=xY61RtDJTbMldNcFMhVE7xNeOos&hl=sv&ei=D1TTTsalBsre4QSslYAX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Mississippi%20Married%20women%201839&f=false Janet L. Coryell: Negotiating boundaries of southern womanhood]</ref> * USA, Maine: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1841 * Bulgaria: The first secular [[girls school]] makes education and the profession of teacher available for women<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA189&dq=feminist+history+serbia&hl=sv&ei=xjvQTuT_ItHS4QTkspBl&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false The Oxford encyclopedia of women in world history, Volym 1 Av Bonnie G. Smith]</ref> * USA, Maryland: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name.<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1842 * Sweden: Compulsory [[Elementary school]] for both sexes <ref>http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/portaler/kunskap/historik/</ref> * USA, New Hampshire: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1843 * USA, Kentucky: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1844 * USA, Maine: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Maine: Married women granted trade license<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Massachusetts: Married Women granted separate economy <ref name="spanalumni.academia.edu">[http://spanalumni.academia.edu/ERoberts/Papers/251656/Womens_Rights_and_Womens_Labor_Married_Womens_Property_Laws_and_Labor_Force_Participation_1860_1900 Evan Roberts: Women's Rights and Women's Labor: Married Women's Property Laws and Labor Force Participation, 1860 1900]</ref> ; 1845 * Sweden: Equal [[inheritance]] for sons and daughters (in the absence of a [[Will (law)|will]])<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979">Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok (Little Focus Encyclopedia) Focus Uppslagsböcker AB (1979) {{sv icon}}</ref> * USA, New York: Married women granted patent rights<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Florida: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1846 * Sweden: Trade- and crafts works professions are opened to all unmarried women<ref name="ub.gu.se">http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/portaler/arbete/artal/</ref> * USA, Alabama: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Kentucky: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Ohio: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Michigan: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1847 * Belgium: [[Elementary school]] for both genders * Costa Rica: The first high school for girls, and the profession of teacher is open to women<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=xl1rbaPN7mIC&pg=PA36&dq=women+history+costa+rica&hl=sv&ei=iALcTsyLK6eA4gS6rd2QDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Ilse Abshagen Leitinger: The Costa Rican women's movement: a reader]</ref> ; 1848 * USA, State of New York: Married Women's Property Act grant married women separate economy<ref>http://www.mccarter.org/Education/mrs-packard/html/MRS.%20PACKARD%20Married%20Women's%20Property%20Act%20Hyperlink.pdf</ref> * USA, Pennsylvania: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Rhode Island: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1849 * USA, Alabama: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Connecticut: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA: [[Elizabeth Blackwell]] becomes the first female medical doctor (1858 also in [[Great Britain]]). * USA, Missouri: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, South Carolina: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1850 * France: Elementary education for both sexes, but girls are only allowed to be tutored by teachers from the church<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * Haiti: The first permanent school for girls<ref name="haiticulture.ch">http://www.haiticulture.ch/Reperes_chronologiques.html</ref> * Iceland: Equal inheritance.<ref name="helsinki.fi">http://www.helsinki.fi/science/xantippa/wle/wle14.html</ref> * USA, California: Married Women's Property Act grant married women separate economy<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=4cwioT5k0IgC&pg=PA485&dq=Massachusetts+1854+married+women+property+act&hl=sv&ei=RcnTTpzBFefi4QT7mKB8&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&sqi=2&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false History of the United States by Charles Austin Beard, Mary Ritter Beard]</ref> * USA, Wisconsin: Married Women's Property Act grant married women separate economy<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=4cwioT5k0IgC&pg=PA485&dq=Massachusetts+1854+married+women+property+act&hl=sv&ei=RcnTTpzBFefi4QT7mKB8&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&sqi=2&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false History of the United States by Charles Austin Beard, Mary Ritter Beard]</ref> * USA, Oregon: Unmarried women are allowed to own land<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> ; 1851 * Guatemala: Full [[citizenship]] are granted economically independent women (rescinded in 1879)<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=mVHA9YVC6GQC&pg=PA281&lpg=PA281&dq=guatemala+women+citizen+1851&source=bl&ots=9zn2i4hoQa&sig=p69KeTpCVV-f53s3WAxAymRQuoo&hl=sv&ei=82nTToqIEZTb4QSmmMQc&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&sqi=2&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=guatemala%20women%20citizen%201851&f=false Sisterhood is global: the international women's movement anthology by Robin Morgan]</ref> * Canada, New Brunswick : Married women granted separate economy<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=AZyE1YVnydMC&pg=PA40&dq=canada+married+women+1859&hl=sv&ei=4dLTTpeVEeij4gTjzck_&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false Courtship, love, and marriage in nineteenth-century English Canada by W. Peter Ward ]</ref> ; 1852 * USA, New Jersey: Married Women granted separate economy <ref name="spanalumni.academia.edu"/> * USA, Indiana: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Wisconsin: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1853 * Colombia: Divorce is legalized (rescinded in 1856 and reintroduced in 1992) <ref>Women's Roles in Latin America and the Caribbean by Kathryn A. Sloan</ref> * Sweden: The profession of teacher at public primary and elementary schools are opened to both sexes<ref>Inger Hultgren (Swedish): Kvinnors organisation och samhällets beslutsprocess (1982)</ref> ; 1854 * Norway: Equal inheritance<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * USA, [[Massachusetts]]: grant married women separate economy<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=4cwioT5k0IgC&pg=PA485&dq=Massachusetts+1854+married+women+property+act&hl=sv&ei=RcnTTpzBFefi4QT7mKB8&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&sqi=2&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false History of the United States by Charles Austin Beard, Mary Ritter Beard]</ref> * Chile: The first public elementary school for girls<ref>The Oxford encyclopedia of women in world history, Volym 1 by Bonnie G. Smith</ref> ; 1855 * USA, Iowa: [[University of Iowa]] becomes the first coeducational [[Public university|public]] or state university in the United States<ref name=Roch>{{Citation | first = A.J. | last = May | title = University of Rochester History | url = http://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=2319 }}</ref> * USA, Michigan: Married women granted separate economy<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA189&dq=feminist+history+serbia&hl=sv&ei=xjvQTuT_ItHS4QTkspBl&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false The Oxford encyclopedia of women in world history, Volym 1 Av Bonnie G. Smith]</ref> ; 1856 * USA, Connecticut: Married women granted patent rights<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1857 * Denmark: Legal majority for unmarried women<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * Denmark: Trade- and crafts professions are opened to unmarried women<ref name="kvinfo.dk">http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/342/</ref> * Great Britain: [[Matrimonial Causes Act 1857]] makes divorce possible for both sexes. * Netherlands: Elementary education compulsory for both girls and boys <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=6PAldcfPLOMC&pg=PA67&dq=women+rights+netherlands&hl=sv&ei=I_TjTsfLC-X54QTHmt2gBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Kaethe Schirmacher: The Modern Woman's Rights Movement]</ref> * Spain: Elementary education compulsory for both girls and boys <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=JCccGd-1upgC&pg=PA156&dq=women+universities+spain+1882&hl=sv&ei=CQfVTvW1L-HO4QT7j_jZAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=women%20universities%20spain%201882&f=false The educated woman: minds, bodies, and women's higher education in Britain, Germany and Spain, by Katharina Rowold]</ref> * USA, Maine: Married women granted the right to control their own earnings <ref name="spanalumni.academia.edu"/> * USA, Oregon: Married women allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Oregon: Married women allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1858 * Russia: [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasiums]] for girls<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> * Sweden: Legal majority for unmarried women (if applied for; automatic legal majority in 1863)<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979"/> ; 1859 * Canada West: Married women granted separate economy <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=AZyE1YVnydMC&pg=PA40&dq=canada+married+women+1859&hl=sv&ei=4dLTTpeVEeij4gTjzck_&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false Courtship, love, and marriage in nineteenth-century English Canada by W. Peter Ward ]</ref> * Denmark: The post of teacher at public schools are opened to women<ref name="kvinfo.dk"/> * Russia: Women allowed to audit university lectures (retracted in 1863)<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> * Sweden: The post of college teacher and lower official at public institutions are open to women <ref>http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/artal/</ref> * USA, Kansas: Married Women's Property Act grant married women separate economy <ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=4cwioT5k0IgC&pg=PA485&dq=Massachusetts+1854+married+women+property+act&hl=sv&ei=RcnTTpzBFefi4QT7mKB8&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&sqi=2&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false History of the United States by Charles Austin Beard, Mary Ritter Beard]</ref>
===1860–1899=== ; 1860 * USA, New York: Married women granted the right to control their own earnings<ref name="spanalumni.academia.edu"/> * USA, Maryland: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Maryland: Married women granted the right to control their earnings<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Maryland: Married women granted trade license<ref name="books.google.se"/> * New Zealand: Married women allowed to own property (extended in 1870)<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * USA, Massachusetts: Married women granted trade licenses<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1861 * France: [[Julie-Victoire Daubié]] becomes the first female student. * Iceland: Legal majority for unmarried women<ref name="helsinki.fi"/> * Russia: The Scientific- and Medical Surgery Academy open laboratories for women (retracted in 1864)<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=women+history+russia+1753&source=bl&ots=B50loPO3ju&sig=Wbl3e_uzS0ygjD3S8XFGrF40fWQ&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=mtP1TtzJHLD74QTs7sWNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Barbara Alpern Engel: Women in Russia, 1700–2000]</ref> * Sweden: The first public institution of higher academic learning for women, [[Högre lärarinneseminariet]], is opened. * Sweden: The [[dentist]] profession is opened to women<ref>Österberg, Carin et al., Svenska kvinnor: föregångare, nyskapare (Swedish women: predecessors, successors) Lund: Signum 1990. (ISBN 91-87896-03-6) (Swedish)</ref> * USA: [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] becomes the first female dentist. * USA, Illinois: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Ohio: Married women granted separate economy<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Illinois: Married women granted control over their earnings<ref name="books.google.se"/> * USA, Ohio: Married women granted control over their earnings<ref name="books.google.se"/> ; 1863 * Denmark: Colleges open to women<ref name="ub.gu.se"/> * Norway: Legal majority for unmarried women (at the same age as men in 1869)<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979"/> * Sweden: The Post- and telegraph professions are opened to women <ref>http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/portaler/kunskap/folkbildning/kvinnstyrken.pdf</ref> ; 1864 * Bohemia: Taxpaying women and women in "learned profession" eligible to the legislative body<ref>[http://www.jstor.org/pss/1946097 P.
